top.value: NIMD, Passage 31, 2511 AB The Hague, The Netherlands

Political actors are defined as the combined main target group of the Strategic Partnership: - (representatives of) political parties - politicians - (Members of) Parliament and its Committees - Other elected representatives at local levels. NIMD will primarily focus on political parties.

Dialogue for Stability: Inclusive politics in fragile settings (2016-2020) The number of countries and regions that are affected by conflict and fragility is globally on the increase. In Central America, a number of countries are hard hit by fragility and criminality; in the Horn of Africa and parts of sub-Saharan and West Africa instability and internal conflict continue to persist and in the MENA region, a number of countries are at risk of collapsing as a result of religious and political sectarianism. Also in the Eastern European neighborhood, high levels of tension and the use of force remain very worrisome. These conflicts are not limited to national borders. Increasingly, international dimensions are at play as the conflicts in Syria and Ukraine painfully reveal. The increasing instability at the eastern and southern borders of Europe also has an immediate effect on Europe’s own security and stability levels, as the current migration flows clearly unfolds. These developments require a fundamental rethink of the strategies and responses by the international community, informed by an in-depth understanding of the underlying root causes of the conflicts and fragility dimensions in these countries. To better understand and define its own role and positioning in the changing world order, NIMD recently embarked on a reflection process as part of the preparations for its multi-annual plan for the period 2016-2020. This resulted in the publication of its new Multi-Annual Plan entitled (MAP): ‘Stronger Parties. Deeper Democracy’. The MAP describes the vision, objectives, challenges and priorities for the period 2016–2020 and is underpinned by an elaborated Theory of Change. Its overall vision is “to contribute to legitimate and inclusive political systems which create favourable conditions for peace and security by accommodating divergent views and interests in society and by setting differences in a non-violent way”. Since NIMD is increasingly working in political environments which are extremely polarised and divided and in countries that moved either just out of conflict, find themselves in conflict or are at risk of moving towards conflict, NIMD has furthermore prepared an approach for working in fragile and conflict-affected settings. In line with NIMD’s Theory of Change, this approach focusses on three interrelated levels related to political system, political actor and political culture change. Over the past few months, NIMD has engaged in consultations with the Stabilisation and Humanitarian Aid Department (DSH) of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to explore the possibilities for the Ministry to continue its support the NIMD beyond the current subsidy that comes to an end in December 2015. The outcome of these deliberations has resulted in the approval of a first grant under the Strategic Partnership for lobby and advocacy and the invitation to submit a five year programme to contribute to inclusive politics in fragile settings and for NIMD institutionally, on knowledge and innovation, monitoring and evaluation and fundraising. This programme called ”Dialogue for Stability: inclusive politics in fragile settings”, particularly aims to contribute to open and accessible political systems and the legitimacy and responsiveness of political actors in countries affected by conflict and fragility. The programme therefore directly contributes to the vision and objectives laid down in NIMD’s MAP and the goals on inclusive political processes and legitimate and capable governments as defined in the policy spearhead on Security and the Rule of Law of the MFA. Furthermore, it contribute to the aim of peaceful and inclusive sustainable development and accountable and inclusive institutions as defined in the 16th Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) recently adopted. NIMD will concentrate its efforts on a selected number of countries (Burundi, South Sudan, Ukraine, Tunisia and Colombia) where it can build on its existing political and partner networks, knowledge base and infrastructure. These country programmes will be based on a country specific baseline and theory of change, informed by an in depth political economy analysis. Furthermore, explorations and a limited number of activities will be conducted in Jordan, Lebanon, Kurdistan and Israel-Palestinian territories. Depending on the political environments and potential entry points in these three countries and one region, they could overtime evolve into fully fledged programmes. Next to these country programmes, the Dialogue for Stability programme will further deepen NIMD’s knowledge base, invest in its skills-set and develop tools and instruments regarding interparty dialogue, capacity strengthening, political culture and gender diversity and inclusiveness. A specific part of NIMD’s knowledge agenda will be devoted to strategies, skills and expertise for working in fragile and conflict affected settings in recognition of the fact that working in such sensitive contexts requires a tailored approach. Furthermore, NIMD will strengthen its knowledge base on new thinking about participatory democracy and stimulate and explore (programmatic and political) innovation in its new and existing programme countries.

BURUNDI’S POLITICAL BACKGROUND Burundi has witnessed decades of violent civil conflict between ethnic groups. Despite the fact that a peace process has made democratic transition possible, strong political distrust and a lack of inclusive dialogue between different groups continue to pose significant challenges. THE APPROACH OF NIMD IN BURUNDI NIMD started to work in Burundi in 2008. The implementing partner organization in Burundi is ‘The Burundi Leadership Training Programme (BLTP)’. In the run up to the 2010 elections, NIMD and BLTP worked on getting the political parties to talk to each other and develop themselves as democratic parties. However, since the 2010 elections – which many opposition parties boycotted – Burundi has experienced several years of serious political deadlock, including a period when the different parties would not meet each other and several opposition leaders lived in exile. In 2013 and 2014, as part of a strategy for unlocking this political deadlock, NIMD and BLTP managed to engage the main 13 political parties in an 18-month capacity building project. This was a series of training sessions on how to develop a political party programme, including topics such as how to write a programme, how to develop policy positions and how to involve members in the provinces in such a process. These were multiparty training sessions so representatives of all the main 13 political parties attended the programme together. So at the same time as providing training on very useful technical information and skills, it was also a significant move towards building trust between the parties. In addition to the different multiparty trainings, NIMD also facilitated the process of parties holding internal party discussions, including consulting with their members in several provinces, and helped them to translate these discussions into policy positions on key issues. 2014 saw the last 6 months of this project and the start of a second project focusing on helping the parties to prepare for participating in the elections in 2015. This consisted of training sessions on topics such as how to select candidates, how to observe elections, how to work within the new electoral legislative framework and how to develop communication strategies for getting messages across to the electorate. These activities were executed both in the capital as well as in provinces esteemed to be potentially risky during elections. NIMD and BLTP also arranged for the independent electoral commission to participate in some of these sessions to enable them to exchange information with the political parties and to increase trust in the management of the electoral process. Democracy Schools Since 2011, NIMD and BLTP have also been running democracy schools in Burundi. The school programme started in two provinces and was aimed at training community leaders in democratic knowledge and skills. Currently, there are schools in 8 provinces. We constantly work on furthering developing the set up of the schools and the curriculum. For instance, the training modules now also address security problems because that is an important issue in Burundi at the moment. This means that the schools are now also open to policemen.   Programme deviations/ToC update: The political crisis that started in 2015, continued in 2016. The nature of political violence changed from popular protests and clashes between protesters and security forces to targeted assassinations of high profile politicians and security officials, extra judicial killings, kidnappings and disappearances. The ruling party has increasingly consolidated its monopoly on power and state institutions. Political space for opposition parties to operate in the country became extremely limited. The Ministry of Home Affairs, charged with the management of political parties, continued the practice of splitting up political parties, creating government controlled versions of opposition parties and denouncing the original. Opposition parties have either seen their leadership assassinated, forced to flee of the country, or unable to organize functionally operating party structures. The exiled leaders of key opposition parties continued to be organised CNARED, a opposition coordination mechanism through which they aim to be recognised and effectively participate in the internationally mediated dialogue process on the Burundi crisis. Due to its composition CNARED remained an unacceptable counterparty for the Burundian government, as they accuse key members of its leadership to have been involved in the attempted coup d’etat of May 2015. The pluriform composition of CNARED also remained a source for internal frictions which further hampered its effectiveness as an opposition platform. 

There have been little indications that the consultations facilitated by former President of Tanzania Mkapa under the auspices of the East African Community have produced a dialogue that will resolve the crisis. In part, this was caused by the hostile position of the ruling party, but the weak and divided opposition also played a role and the absence of sufficient coherent political front of the Heads of State in the EAC region formed a further explanatory factor. The efforts of the UN to support this process and new resolutions of the UN Security Council have also been met with outright refusal and condemnation from the Government of Burundi. In the meantime the Government of Burundi has pushed forward its own internal Burundian consultation process led by the National Commission for Inter-Burundian Dialogue (CNDI). This has been seen as a way to produce pre-determined conclusions that will endorse the position of the ruling party and could pave the way for constitutional amendments that will remove presidential term limits, ethnic quota linked to the Arusha peace agreement and enable further reforms that will negatively impact on political space. While a constitutional revision has not yet taken place, several  laws were passed and CSOs were banned that has already significantly reduced the democratic and civil space. These processes are expected to continue in the following year. 

A solution or breakthrough from one of the (international) dialogue attempts has failed to take place. At the same time, Nkurunziza’s position has not been substantially challenged by newly formed armed opposition groups, among other reasons because they did not have sufficient capacity to sustain an armed rebellion. 

Throughout the year, there have been speculations that internal divisions within the ruling party and security forces could lead to a challenge to the President’s power from within, but given the failed coup attempt in 2015 it is difficult to assess if this was a realistic scenario at any point during 2016. The threat of rapid deterioration into widespread political and ethnic violence in this case, which could have been the trigger for an international peacekeeping intervention, has not fully vanished at any point of the year. The year 2016 as such, closed with almost as much uncertainty as it started. A continuation of the current political deadlock therefore also presents itself as a likely scenario for (the first part of) 2017.

After the consolidation phase in 2016 using the existing knowledge and (re)capturing and updating this, the year 2017 will focus on developing several new tools and knowledge products. The start-up programmes in the Middle East will benefit from support to designing tailor-made instruments that will be based on the regular NIMD toolkit, while the FCAS approach will see deepening of knowledge in 2 of the 6 focus areas (conversion of (former) armed movements into political parties and fostering inclusive political settlements) combined with new communication products (animation and documentary). Under the innovating democracy programme two more pilots will be organised (most likely Myanmar and Georgia) plus a follow-up ‘hackathon’ in Colombia related to developing a democracy app. Moreover, building on the 2016 Innovation symposium, an expert network will be set-up that will link academia, civic-tech practitioners and politicians to focus on new forms of representative democracy and the role of political parties in this.

1. Political update 2017
Political polarization, informal governance and the parliamentary elections of October 8th, defined Georgia’s political landscape in 2016. The polarization between the two main parties, the ruling Georgian Dream (GD) and the United National Movement (UNM) of former president Mr. Saakashvili did not recede. While GD’s overall approval rankings shrank in 2016 and the coalition itself fell apart (after the Free Democrats Party and later, the Republicans left), the UNM had difficulties to re-shape itself and expand its electoral base. This polarization contributed to the deterioration of citizens’ trust in the parliament and in political parties. The two individuals heading the parties continued to exert power from beyond the formal framework of politics and governance. While Michael Saakashvili, currently the Governor of Odessa in Ukraine, continued to address and mobilize (via video messages and online) support to UNM, the former Prime Minister, Bidzina Ivanishvili, remained a defining political force for GD and its governance while officially distancing himself from any political role and therefore denying responsibility. This is a fundamental problem, as governance without accountability undermines the credibility of political institutions and risks portraying democracy as a cover-up for behind the scenes influence by interest groups and individuals. 
The elections of October 08, 2016 were generally appraised by international observers as free and fair, solidifying Georgia’s position of as a regional leader in democratic reforms. However, there are challenges that merit closer attention: The inability of pro-democracy political parties (The Republicans and the Free Democrats) to clear the 5% electoral threshold has weakened democratic forces in the country. The rise of the nationalistic “Alliance of Georgian Patriots,” which was able to gain enough votes to clear the electoral threshold is a clear sign of disillusionment of the Georgian voters with standing politics and shows that anti-democratic propaganda has taken root in Georgia. 

2. Programme & Theory of Change Update
With GD currently primed to obtain super majority in the Parliament, it will be highly important that it does not turn its constitutional majority into a political weapon against the UNM and in favour of its own partisan interests; political pluralism must survive and thrive; efforts will need to be made to strengthen democratic political groups both within GD and UNM as well as in other groups and political parties. Therefore, the NIMD will continue its efforts to address the capacity of political actors, further improve the political and electoral playing field and enhance democratic political culture. This will be done through bilateral support programs to political parties, multilateral dialogue efforts to advance the participation of women, youth and national minorities and the operation of Democracy Schools. In 2017, as well as onwards, NIMD’s theory of change of simultaneously addressing the interrelated issues related to political actors, culture and system will attain heightened importance amidst rising anti-democratic sentiments, decreasing trust in political parties and further deepening polarization between the GD and the UNM, with a yet unclear role for the populist and anti-western Alliance of Georgian Patriots to play in that setting.

1. Political update 2017 

Political elites and vested interests continue to dominate Indonesia's political system. Political outsiders can only join one of the established political parties and legislative election is dominated by individuals with political or business nexus thus providing limited opportunities for substantive reforms. The extensive power of the parliament to scrutinise and influence the national policies are often under-utilized due to lack of capacity of the Members of Parliament (MPs). Political parties invest little in training and education of their cadres to become good legislators that resulted in low policy initiatives and legislative products.  
In recent times, the youth has been invited to participate in politics but they are lacking in capacity and political power due to tight control of party oligarchs and absence of internal party democracy. The potentials within the youth as agents of change have not been maximally utilized and even those who are members of the political parties and MPs are given few opportunities or strategic positions thus becoming an obstacle to the development of an inclusive representative politics.  
The main reason for non-responsive political parties is related to their focus on power-gaining and power-sharing rather than serving the constituents. Engagement with their constituents is rare, except during elections. Coalitions between parties are mostly based on obtaining a share in power, mostly in the form of political appointments, and not on a trade-off of ideas and policies. Thus, the coalitions of parties is broad and fluid with little programmatic coherence. Furthermore, the virtually indistinguishable party programmes and ideologies, except perhaps between the Islamic and nationalist parties, makes it difficult for voters to hold parties and politicians accountable for their actions and potentially obstructs idea-based constructive political dialogue.  
On political culture, there is a low level of substantive civil-political consultations. The citizens also have few avenues to directly voice their concerns and opinions except by voting in elections which has little impact when it is the same familiar faces running for office and ineffective reses visits. Geographical distance between the politicians in Jakarta and their constituents which are dispersed across the archipelago and a lack of understanding among MPs as "people's representatives" added to the challenge. Additionally, there is an utter lack of public trust in the political parties that deepened the disconnect between the two that could further hinder the responsiveness and accountability of parties.
2. Programme & Theory of Change Update
The programme outlook for 2017 is very much in line with the original INSPIRE programme proposal. The programme will remain to be focussed on setting up and facilitating multiparty dialogue amongst young MP’s on issues of shared concern. Capacity strengthening will be added to the programme to strengthen the capacity of the target group in their dialogue skills but also building capacity and providing (innovative) means to contribute to informed debates. Furthermore we will start with activities supporting the parties towards becoming more programmatic.
In 2017 we will start actively linking the participating MPs with relevant civil society representatives, making use of Kemitraan’s wide network but also linking the politicians with a representative group of alumni of the former ‘democracy schools’ programme.     

The Theory of Change will remain unchanged in the light of the political update.

1. Political update 2017
Ghana has been considered the beacon of democracy in West Africa in recent years as it has experienced a number of years of political stability and economic growth. Yet over time cleavages in the socio political environment have arisen especially relating to political inclusiveness and responsiveness. Especially the youth feel disenfranchised in politics, while women are severely unrepresented.
In 2016 political developments have centred on the parliamentary and presidential elections planned for December 2016. There are over 20 presidential candidates supported by a range of new parties. The incumbent and his party (NDC) is deeply unpopular. In late 2015 a number of corruption scandals, including one leading to the suspension of seven high court judges, and lavish government spending led to a number of large public protests in the capital early in the year. The perception among the population that the government mismanaged the recent sharp economic downturn and power crisis which led to steep increases in the price of energy and water, fuelled by the reality of a large budge assistance programme introduced by the IMF last April, has only made the ruling party even more unpopular. 
The main opposition candidate however comes from the second largest party (NPP) that has faced a number of internal party struggles recently regarding its presidential candidate. The party is also struggling with financing its activities. Despite these problems the NPP is expected to win the presidential election overwhelmingly. 
There also continues to be a lot of distrust in the Electoral commission and their ability to manage the elections is being questioned. To support the management of the elections an elections taskforce has been established, that includes the national police force, who are specifically working on preventing electoral violence, all the political parties also signed a communique urging people to not resort to violence. 
However trust in politics is at an all-time low and political actors will need to work hard to create a more inclusive environment that addresses the corruption and transparency issues they face. The new government will inherit a massive debt problem and an as yet unresolved power crisis. Meanwhile education and unemployment remain high on the political agenda. Political stakeholders will also need to review the way in which elections are managed to ensure more trust in the Electoral commission in the future. 

2. Programme & Theory of Change Update
The theory of change for the Ghana programme focuses on improving the political system, actors and culture through the inclusion of youth and women’s voices in policy making. This is still a very persistent issue in Ghanaian politics as the run up to the presidential elections show primarily an old guard political elite contesting for power. 
The programme this year has focussed on preparing youth leaders to engage in the elections in a productive manner and from next year once the elections have taken place the programme aims to develop a shadow dialogue platform that enables youth leaders to interact with each other and the political leadership to ensure inclusive policy making on topics that affect them. For this reason the changing political context supports the theory of change and the programme objectives even more deeply.
Besides implementing programme activities in 2017 NIMD, together with our local partner, will also develop a plan to ensure the programme’s sustainability beyond 2018 (at which point MFA funding will cease). By early 2017 NIMD will have developed its vision for the future of the programme on the basis of possible scenarios and opportunities currently available. In the first quarter of 2017 NIMD together with its local partner will decide how this goal can best be achieved, including what resources and funding will be necessary. For the remainder of the year the plan will be implemented so that by 2018 a sustainable programme is in place.

1. Political update 2017 
The first half of 2016 saw continued deterioration in Mozambique’s military and economic crisis, with increased attacks on the road which links the North and South of the country. Increasing public debt contributed to the country’s financial and economic crises. 

Parliament has been actively involved in discussions on the political and economic situation, with those holding seats in their provincial assemblies appealing to their constituents to end the violence. A parliamentary commission was established to deal with the public debt issue and it has called upon government to explain how this debt was contracted without Parliament’s approval. 

There have also been several civil society protests calling on government and the main opposition, RENAMO, to end the military attacks. Intimidation of civil society activists has been on the rise with reports of murders and attempted murders. 

While attacks continue, the situation is improving amidst internationally mediated negotiations brought in at RENAMO’s request. The hope is that the parties involved in the negotiations reach consensus as soon as possible.


2. Programme & Theory of Change Update
There has been no obvious cause for deviation from the programme and ToC. If anything, the developments in the country have re-enforced the need for the programme and demand for support from programme partners has increased. Civil society is being further marginalised, as evidenced by their exclusion from the negotiation processes where they are not allowed to participate even as observers. 

Together with partners, the programme will be better positioned to closely assess the programme’s relevance within the context of the ToC at the start of the second year of implementation.

Il s’agit des trois (03) analyses d’économie politique (AEPs) et des trois (03) études sur le coût de la politique du Burkina Faso, Mali et Niger, réalisées en 2019.

Les organisations régionales et internationales souffrent d’un déficit de légitimité auprès des citoyens qui souvent réagissent plus pour s’opposer aux organisations comme la CEDEAO et aux pays comme la France que pour défendre les gouvernants dont ils contestent en même temps la légitimité. Les organisations régionales et internationales, en ne se positionnant pas fermement sur les principes de gouvernance, deviennent des bouc-émissaires de la crise qui secoue le Mali.

Le NIMD Sahel met en œuvre les écoles politiques et démocratiques. Il est prévu de mettre en place un réseau d’alumni pour suivre les trajectoires des jeunes et femmes formés. Comme c’est la première expérience de l’équipe dans les écoles démocratiques, le savoir-faire de CEMI peut aider le NIMD Sahel à mieux suivre les alumni.
Il s’agit des trois (03) analyses d’économie politique (AEPs) et trois (03) études sur le cout de la politique (COP) du Burkina Faso, Mali et Niger, réalisées en 2019

Le dialogue a du mal à se formaliser entre d’une part les citoyens et les acteurs politiques et d’autre part, entre les acteurs politiques eux-mêmes à cause de la crise de confiance qui caractérise les relations entre les différents acteurs. Le dernier dialogue tenu est le dialogue national inclusif qui n’a pas échappé aux critiques d’absence de diversité et d’inclusivité faute de consensus sur l’approche méthodologique.

Prior to the coup, women were already highly active in the informal peace process and forming networks of collaboration. The coup has galvanized these networks, which have a longstanding reputation of organizing and engagement due to their strong civil society activism, primarily through ethnic women’s organizations.

Le NIMD Sahel à travers ses bureaux au Burkina, Mali et Niger continue son introduction auprès des organisations régionales comme le G5 Sahel, et des organisations étrangères qui interviennent dans le Sahel pour préparer le terrain aux futures activités de lobbying et de plaidoyer. 
L’idée est de mutualiser les efforts avec l’IG afin de partager nos résultats avec la CEDEAO. Le réseau de Gorée pourra contribuer à cette fin. Il y’a une nécessité de redynamiser la communication et la collaboration avec l’IG pour élargir la portée de nos activités.

La question de gouvernance et de démocratie est reléguée au second plan dans la résolution de conflits dans le Sahel, au Mali en particulier. Or, l’hypothèse est que la crise de gouvernance engendre toutes les autres formes de crise. Pourtant, ces causes qui sont à l’origine de cette instabilité politique et sécuritaire au Sahel, révèlent une fragilisation de la démocratie accentuée par la mauvaise gouvernance et l’exclusion de la majorité des citoyens des accès aux postes électifs et nominatifs.

Due to the difficult situation for programme to operate in Myanmar, by the end of 2021 we expect situation to remain the same, as described under baseline description.

Une campagne de lobbying et de plaidoyer mise en œuvre au niveau régional à l’endroit de la CEDEAO ou de l’Union européenne demande du temps et de la coordination entre les différents partenaires du NIMD Sahel. De ce fait, cette année sera consacrée à l’identification des partenaires et leur mise en contact dans les trois pays.

Le NIMD Sahel et l’IG saisiront l’opportunité du réexamen du Protocol additionnel sur la démocratie et la bonne gouvernance de 2001 pour redynamiser les échanges et convenir des préalables afin de développer des stratégies communes de lobbying et de plaidoyer à l’endroit des citoyens ouest-africains d’une part et de la CEDEAO d’autre part pour une mobilisation en faveur d’une application effective et non sélective du Protocole additionnel de la CEDEAO.
En 2021, chaque pays a approfondi son AEP sur une question spécifique, et les résultats ont servi de base à la planification et la programmation des activités.

Compte-tenu du démarrage du nouveau programme et de l’agenda des différents partenaires, il sera difficile de mettre en commun nos réseaux et développer une synergie avant la fin de l’année. Cependant, les premiers contacts entre les différents partenaires du consortium seront établis dès cette année.

Définir avec AMwA les grandes lignes de l’audit genre. Une formation de l’équipe NIMD Sahel dans la programmation sensible au genre sera faite. Et le NIMD Sahel pourra étendre la formation à ses partenaires locaux pour faire face au défi de la participation des femmes et à la prise en compte de leurs préoccupations dans la gouvernance.
